[@josiah](@HjH7assXYIZ5ATQkh1CKtnt6lpVVDY24/NB29okNido=.ed25519)

> Curious why using -'s is more accessible for screen readers.

I suppose I shouldn't have specified only hyphens, other word separators work fine, but hyphens seem to be the most common on here. The idea is to avoid jumbled hashtags like #thisexample because lots of software will parse it as one big word. Alternatively, you can use:

- **CamelCase:** #ThisExample
- **Hyphenation:** #this-example
- **Underscore (uncommon):** #this_example

My tendency is to use hyphens so that it isn't affected by uppercase/lowercase shenanigans, but that may be a personal preference. It's worth noting that [the Unicode standard](http://unicode.org/reports/tr31/#hashtag_identifiers) specifies that hashtags can use `-`, `_`, or `+`, so those are all technically valid contendors.

I've been dreaming up some idea on #synonyms and how to merge channels/tags that only differ on word separation, but that's a story for another thread.
